description:
Set in a far flung medieval-looking world of Arst, Prince Jordy Volder takes up the fight against the ambitions of the conqueror Marder. Jordy uses the legendary giant robot "panzer" Galient, which is one of many panzers that have been preserved underground for thousands of years. Using an army of advanced robot panzers, Marder is conquering all of Arst in preparation of his plan for dominance of the Crescent Galaxy.

(Source: Wikipedia)

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

name.native: ジョルディ・ボーダー
ジルムセン・ランベル

node.description:
Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).
Kunio Okawara was the first in the industry to be specifically credited as a mechanical designer. He is the designer of numerous Real Robots and Super Robots.

[Website](http://www.yatate.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yatate_hajime) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢立肇) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Yatate)

Hajime Yatate is a collective pseudonym for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s staff.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋良輔_(アニメ監督%29)

Originally from [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/). He is one of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s most influential figures, pioneering and evolving the "real robot" genre of anime with shows such as [Taiyou no Kiba Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/) and [Soukou Kihei Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/).

Perhaps most well known for his work as a character designer on the anime television series [Armored Trooper Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/). He was also one of the founding members of [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/), together with [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/), and Koushin Yonekawa.

In 1966, Shioyama joined Hatena Pro under the direction of [Bonjin Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/117141/). Shioyama later became a freelancer, doing work for [Tatsunoko Pro](https://anilist.co/studio/103/) and working on many projects for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as an animation director. Shioyama's first project as a character designer was for [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), which anime director [Ryousuke Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100957/) praised. He then worked on such shows as [Fang of the Sun Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/), [Panzer World Galient](https://anilist.co/anime/5153/), and [Ronin Warriors](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) as both character designer and animation director. His and Takahashi's designs epitomized Sunrise's work in the '80s.

On April 13, 2017, a fire occurred at Shioyama's apartment in Misato, sadly killing both him and his wife.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋良輔_(アニメ監督%29)

Originally from [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/). He is one of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s most influential figures, pioneering and evolving the "real robot" genre of anime with shows such as [Taiyou no Kiba Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/) and [Soukou Kihei Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/).

Perhaps most well known for his work as a character designer on the anime television series [Armored Trooper Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/). He was also one of the founding members of [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/), together with [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/), and Koushin Yonekawa.

In 1966, Shioyama joined Hatena Pro under the direction of [Bonjin Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/117141/). Shioyama later became a freelancer, doing work for [Tatsunoko Pro](https://anilist.co/studio/103/) and working on many projects for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as an animation director. Shioyama's first project as a character designer was for [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), which anime director [Ryousuke Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100957/) praised. He then worked on such shows as [Fang of the Sun Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/), [Panzer World Galient](https://anilist.co/anime/5153/), and [Ronin Warriors](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) as both character designer and animation director. His and Takahashi's designs epitomized Sunrise's work in the '80s.

On April 13, 2017, a fire occurred at Shioyama's apartment in Misato, sadly killing both him and his wife.

He was affiliated with [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) throughout the '80s and '90s.

*Note: Not to be confused with the [background artist and painter](https://anilist.co/staff/163275).*

A notable mechanical and character designer for both anime and tokusatsu series.

He aspired a career in the industry after having seen [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), a franchise in which he would eventually serve as a director [in 2012](https://anilist.co/anime/12029/). His career began in 1978, debuting as a mechanical designer on [Toushou Daimos](https://anilist.co/anime/2816/), designing the enemy robots. Few years later in 1981, he made his tokusatsu debut on Robot 8-chan.

The following decade he worked on industry shaping series such as [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/) and [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/). During this time he also had ties to Parallel Creation, a creative group led by sci-fi writer [Aritsune Toyota](https://anilist.co/staff/220367/). This led him to work as an illustrator on novels such as [Record of Lodoss War](https://anilist.co/manga/92655/), in which his designs were deeply influential for Japanese fantasy series.

In 2002, he directed [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/), an anime original created by him. Izubuchi said that his attempt was to set a new standard for mecha anime, as well as to bring back aspects of '70s mecha shows like [Brave Raideen](https://anilist.co/anime/2128/).

A trademark in his mechanical designs is the Buchi-hole (ブチ穴), a series of round holes embedded, usually in a cluster pattern of three holes above and two below, located somewhere on the mecha.
Mitsuharu Miyamae is an art director.

Toriumi Jinzou was a Japanese screenwriter who first began his career during the "revolutionary era" of Japanese animation on Mach Go Go Go (Speed Racer), Science Ninja Team Gatchaman (Battle of the Planets/G-Force) and Yatterman.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%B1%A0%E7%94%B0%E6%88%90)

Masashi Ikeda is a director, screenwriter and storyboard artist.

Noted for directing [Mobile Suit Gundam Wing](https://anilist.co/anime/90/), [Vampire Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1952/) and the first 44 episodes of [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/). He is a former member of an amateur anime production circle "Group Ebisen," together with [Hiroyuki Kakudou](https://anilist.co/staff/141183/), [Kouji Yamamura](https://anilist.co/staff/101065/), [Keiko Fukuyama](https://anilist.co/staff/159650/), [Sunao Katabuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/103947/), [Umanosuke Iida](Umanosuke Iida) and Takuya Ishida.

Perhaps most well known for his work as a character designer on the anime television series [Armored Trooper Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/). He was also one of the founding members of [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/), together with [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/), and Koushin Yonekawa.

In 1966, Shioyama joined Hatena Pro under the direction of [Bonjin Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/117141/). Shioyama later became a freelancer, doing work for [Tatsunoko Pro](https://anilist.co/studio/103/) and working on many projects for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as an animation director. Shioyama's first project as a character designer was for [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), which anime director [Ryousuke Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100957/) praised. He then worked on such shows as [Fang of the Sun Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/), [Panzer World Galient](https://anilist.co/anime/5153/), and [Ronin Warriors](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) as both character designer and animation director. His and Takahashi's designs epitomized Sunrise's work in the '80s.

On April 13, 2017, a fire occurred at Shioyama's apartment in Misato, sadly killing both him and his wife.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/康村諒)

Since 2012, he was president of [Seven Arcs](https://anilist.co/studio/35/Seven-Arcs) but retired from the company in March 2019.
Started his career at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1963. Later went freelance to further pursue his career as a scriptwriter.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/8tabe5817) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuyoshi_Yatabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷田部勝義)

Yatabe Katsuyoshi is a Japanese screenwriter and director.     

After graduating he joined the Department of Arts at Nihon Daigaku in 1975. In 1978 he joined Ad Cosmo but felt that as subcontractor there would be no real productions done and thus went on to join Sunrise in 1979. There he learned under [Tomino Yoshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97337) and [Takahashi Ryousuke](https://anilist.co/staff/100957) before becoming freelancer.
Founder of [Nakamura Production](https://anilist.co/studio/6658/) together with his brother [Kazuo Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/235139/).

After having graduated from Tokyo Designer Gakuin, she joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), and started off as an animator. She is noted as the first female mecha director, and one of the few female directors in the '80s alongside [Makoto Moriwaki](https://anilist.co/staff/109581/) and [Hiroko Tokita](https://anilist.co/staff/101903/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Ami_Tomobuki)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Ami_Tomobuki)

After having graduated from Tokyo Designer Gakuin, she joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), and started off as an animator. She is noted as the first female mecha director, and one of the few female directors in the '80s alongside [Makoto Moriwaki](https://anilist.co/staff/109581/) and [Hiroko Tokita](https://anilist.co/staff/101903/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/康村諒)

Since 2012, he was president of [Seven Arcs](https://anilist.co/studio/35/Seven-Arcs) but retired from the company in March 2019.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%B1%A0%E7%94%B0%E6%88%90)

Masashi Ikeda is a director, screenwriter and storyboard artist.

Noted for directing [Mobile Suit Gundam Wing](https://anilist.co/anime/90/), [Vampire Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1952/) and the first 44 episodes of [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/). He is a former member of an amateur anime production circle "Group Ebisen," together with [Hiroyuki Kakudou](https://anilist.co/staff/141183/), [Kouji Yamamura](https://anilist.co/staff/101065/), [Keiko Fukuyama](https://anilist.co/staff/159650/), [Sunao Katabuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/103947/), [Umanosuke Iida](Umanosuke Iida) and Takuya Ishida.
